awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A New Theory of Social Choice for More than Two Alternatives: Combining Economics, Statistics, and Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposal aims at generating computational mechanisms that will enable individuals to contribute towards making better collective decisions (e.g., news ranking) including crowdsourcing where aggregation of online noise answers can occur. The proposal brings together ideas from economics, statistics, and computation to expand the capabilities of social choice mechanisms to handle large numbers of alternative choices, to extract ground truth from aggregated preferences, and to address problems where individual agents might not be able to compare some alternatives. In contrast to classical social choice theory, which is limited to the selection between two alternatives, the project proposes a rigorous study of a model for computational choice that will be robust enough for discerning between thousands or even millions of alternatives.

The proposal could have a profound impact in the way we build multi-agent systems, search engines and recommender systems. The proposed effort can serve as a catalyst in the growing area of computational social choice, including: (1) Rank aggregation has been used in many fields, involving some high impact applications like ranking of news. However, this problem is far from solved using traditional computational social choice methods because they either only work for two alternatives, require full rankings, does poorly in revealing the ground truth, or are hard to compute. The proposed research will develop new methodologies to overcome these deficiencies by designing objective, robust, and computable social choice mechanisms for rich preferences.  (2) Crowdsourcing, whereby online workers' noisy answers are aggregated to produce a better overall answer to some question. This cannot be solved by existing computational social choice techniques as the online workers' answers are often partial orders, workers may manipulate the outcome by providing false answers, and the objective of aggregation is to reveal the true answer. The proposed research will directly tackle these challenges by designing new mechanisms, which are directly applicable to existing systems.

por.por_cntn:
Overview of Goals

Social choice is a fundamental problem, where a group of agents make a collective decision based on their preferences. The major goal of this project is to establish a new theory of social choice by developing new principles and methodologies to combine economics, statistics, and computer science. The project aims at developing general frameworks for researchers and practitioners to discover new mechanisms as well as new paradigms that can potentially guide future directions.

Intellectual Merit

Direction 1: Truth-revealing social choice. Research in this direction can be categorized into the following two sub-directions.

1.1  Preference learning. The PI and collaborators established the first set of (non)identifiability results of popular statistical models for preferences, especially the Placket-Luce model [ZPX ICML-16], the more general Random utility models [ZVX AAAI-18], and models with features [ZLX IJCAI-23]. These results reveal critical flaws in the trustworthiness of model interpretation in previous work. The PI and collaborators also designed efficient algorithms for learning and aggregating uncertain preferences [HHX UAI-15, ZLW+ UAI-18, ZX ICML-18, LWLX AAAI-19].

1.2  Truth-revealing and other desiderata. The PI proved the first impossibility theorem on the incompatibility of truth-revealing and social choice desiderata [Xia UAI-16]. The PI and collaborators also considered mechanisms? truth-revealing ability when agents are strategic, identified conditions for truth-telling to be a Nash Equilibrium [Xia AAAI-16], and identified conditions for the group decision in Nash Equilibria to coincide with the majority decision as if the ground truth is revealed to all agents [HSTX EC-23].

Direction 2: Social choice for partial preferences. Research in this direction can be categorized into the following two sub-directions.

2.1  Learning partial preferences. The PI and collaborators have extended the random utility models to handle structured partial orders [ZX NeurIPS-19], general partial orders [LZL+ AAAI-19], and situations where agents and alternatives have features [ZLX IJCAI-23]. In each case, the PI and collaborators also established (non)identifiability results and designed efficient algorithms.

2.2  Desiderata under partial preferences. For resource allocation of multiple types of items, which is an important social choice scenario of partial preferences, the PI and collaborators proposed natural language based on CP-nets and designed various mechanisms for resource allocation, and investigates desiderata of the new mechanisms [WSG+ AAAI-20, GSW+ JAAMAS-21, WSG+ AIJ-23].

Direction 3: Statistical and machine learning frameworks for new mechanisms. Research in this direction can be categorized into the following four sub-directions.

3.1  Automated design. To incorporate fairness and efficiency into AI-powered group decision making, the PI and collaborators have developed a machine-learning-based framework to explore tradeoffs between fairness, efficiency, and privacy [MLC+ JAIR-22]. This framework is flexible and can incorporate classical social choice axiom as well as newly learned desiderata [KKX HCOMP-22].  

3.2  Privacy. The PI and collaborators investigated privacy guarantees of commonly-studied deterministic voting rules  [LLXZ UAI-20] and privacy-fairness tradeoff in social choice [LLX+ AAAI-23].

3.3  Richer dynamics. The PI and collaborators proposed novel frameworks and dynamics for discovering new mechanisms, such as hypothesis testing [Xia UAI-20], iterative voting [KX NeurIPS-21], proxy voting [AFVX AAAI-21], and those of representative democracy [MX NeurIPS-18].

3.4  Beyond the worst-case evaluation. The PI leveraged smoothed analysis to establish a general and more realistic model for group decision making [Xia NeurIPS-20] and developed a ?polyhedral approach? [Xia NeurIPS-20, Xia EC-21, Xia EC-23] to accurately analyze various notions of fairness and efficiency. Straightforward corollaries address decades-long open questions on the likelihood of impossibility of transitivity, impossibility of fairness, impossibility of strategy-proofness, and the doctrinal paradox [LX AAAI-22], showing that the likelihood of these failures is small in many applications. Semi-random complexity of social choice were also initiated and investigated by the PI and collaborators [XZ AAAI-21, XZ WINE-22].

Some results are summarized in a book [Xia-19] and a survey [Xia Annals NYAS-22] by the PI.

Broader Impacts:

OPRA and PrefPy. The open-source Online Preference Reporting and Aggregation (OPRA) system [CQW+ AAAI-21] and the open-source PrefPy package were initiated and developed as part of the project, which continued to provide service to the RPI community and the public.

Students. Three Ph.D. students, four M.S. students, and 26 undergraduate students (including one REU student) were involved and trained in the project.

Organization of workshop and conference. The project supported the PI to host and co-chair the Seventh International Workshop on Computational Social Choice (COMSOC-18) and the 18th Conference on Web and Internet Economics (WINE-22) at RPI.
